title: Kiehl's vintage-looking script logo
content:
Im looking for a typeface similar to this one. Its also for a logotype and I would like to try it of with the client before engaging in any custom work. Any ideas or suggestions?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [kiehls.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20141118212252/http:/typophile.com/files/kiehls.gif) | 8.65 KB |
author: P_P

comments.content: Hm, this one could be a hard one to match. Have you looked at [Radio](http://web.archive.org/web/20141118212252/http:/www.vllg.com/Thirstype/Radio/mudTyper+Weights/) yet? It's gorgeous and very modern, despite its vintage roots.

You could take a stroll through [Jason Walcott](http://web.archive.org/web/20141118212252/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Jason%20Walcott)'s offerings from the [Jukebox Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20141118212252/http:/www.veer.com/products/vendor.aspx?vendor=jbt) foundry.

I think a bolded [Shelley Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20141118212252/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&startrow=1&records=&currpage=1&totalrecords=3&displayfontid=LH.457.0.0&fontRendererText=Kiehl%27s) would be pretty close, if you used two of them to get the right mix of ascenders. Notice the non-looping 'h' ascender in Andante, and looping 'l' in Volante, and similar K in Andante.

The mismatched ascenders were the hardest feature to find.

- Mike Yanega
Shelley is perfect! Thank you for taking time with the ascenders.
Jukebox has some interesting fonts aswell. Thank you for your help.
